M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, a court may modify a custody or parenting time judgment if there has occurred a **material and substantial change in the circumstances** of the parties and if modification is necessary in the **best interests of the children**.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this matter concerns modification of a custody order originally issued by the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this matter concerns modification of a custody order originally issued by the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Continuation of the present custody and parenting time order under these changed circumstances would be contrary to the **best interests of the children** as required by M.G.L. c. 208, § 31.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: See Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) (modification proper where change affects child’s best interests).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition describes Yannas as a case about when a *modification* is proper based on changes affecting the child’s best interests. Yannas, however, is a removal/custody case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a complaint for modification. The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the ‘real advantage’/best‑interests standard for permitting removal, but it does not address standards for modifying an existing custody or support order due to changed circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [a child] shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: See also Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (court must consider changed circumstances and best interests when revisiting parenting schedule).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context, not a general modification of a parenting schedule. While the court does apply a “best interests” standard and notes ALI Principles language that relocation constitutes a substantial change of circumstances, it does not articulate any general rule that a court must consider changed circumstances and best interests when revisiting a parenting schedule. The opinion is focused on the standard for authorizing removal, not on revisiting or modifying parenting time in general.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Where physical custody is shared, the ‘best interest’ calculus pertaining to removal is appreciably different from those situations that involve sole physical custody.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: In Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), the Appeals Court held that modification of custody may be appropriate when one parent’s new employment schedule interferes with the children’s stability and routine.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold that a change in a parent’s employment schedule interfering with stability and routine can justify modification of custody. Instead, the court explicitly states that the mother’s hectic work schedule, by itself, would not warrant modification and finds that any later changes to her schedule were positive and not a basis for changing custody. The holding reverses a custody change and reiterates that a material and substantial change in circumstances—other than relocation—must be shown; it does not recognize new employment schedules as a proper ground here.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification. Second, by the time of trial, the probate judge found that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule ‘allowed her to spend more time with the minor child.’ … Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.”

Custody of Viera, 442 Mass. 690 (2004).proposition: Custody of Viera, 442 Mass. 690 (2004), recognized the central duty of the court to ensure a child’s safety and consistency when evaluating material changes in a parent’s circumstances.
Custody of Viera, 442 Mass. 690 (2004).support_reasoning: The opinion is a sexually dangerous person civil-commitment case focused on statutory speedy-trial deadlines under G. L. c. 123A, § 14(a). It does not involve child custody, material changes in a parent’s circumstances, or the court’s duty to ensure a child’s safety or consistency. Nothing in the holding or reasoning articulates or analyzes a “central duty” to protect a child in custody determinations, so using this case for that proposition is inaccurate.
Custody of Viera, 442 Mass. 690 (2004).relevant_excerpt: “In view of the language of G. L. c. 123A, § 14 (a), and in light of the significance of an individual’s freedom, the Commonwealth must ensure that trial is commenced within sixty days unless the judge makes a finding, based on supporting evidence, that there is good cause to continue the trial or that it is otherwise in the interests of justice to do so.”

Birchall, petitioner, 454 Mass. 837 (200.proposition: Birchall, petitioner, 454 Mass. 837 (2009), emphasizes the trial court’s broad equitable power to revise custody orders in light of evolving family circumstances.
Birchall, petitioner, 454 Mass. 837 (200.support_reasoning: The case concerns supplementary process, civil contempt, and standards/burdens for incarcerating a judgment debtor for failure to pay a monetary judgment. It does not involve child custody, parenting time, or domestic relations, nor does it discuss the trial court’s equitable authority to revise custody orders in light of changed family circumstances. The proposition mischaracterizes the subject and holding of the opinion.
Birchall, petitioner, 454 Mass. 837 (200.relevant_excerpt:
"The court may at any time renew, revise, modify, suspend or revoke any order made in any proceedings . . . ." G. L. c. 224, § 16.

Our review is confined to whether the petitioner may continue to be incarcerated for civil contempt... We also take this opportunity to revise the standard for a finding of civil contempt in all actions, not only supplementary process actions.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), held that nocturnal work schedules may justify modification when such employment materially interferes with parental obligations.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt does not mention nocturnal work schedules, employment hours, or any work-related interference with parental obligations. Instead, it focuses on the general principle that custody determinations must be based on the child’s best interests and cannot be used to punish a parent for misconduct. Therefore, it does not establish or discuss the specific proposition about nocturnal work schedules justifying modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), establishes that parental fitness and ability to meet children’s needs remain controlling factors in best‑interest determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child and the perpetrator’s parenting ability in custody decisions. It does not set out or re‑affirm a general rule that parental fitness and ability to meet the child’s needs remain the controlling factors in best‑interest determinations; that broader principle comes from other Massachusetts custody cases, not this one. Vaughn refines best‑interest analysis by emphasizing domestic violence, rather than articulating parental fitness as the controlling factor.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015), reiterates that stability of care and consistency of parental availability are crucial in custody modifications.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the exact phrasing of the proposition, but in remanding the removal issue it explicitly emphasizes that, in determining the child’s best interests, the court must give weight to stability and avoid unnecessary disruption of the status quo. It cites Custody of Kali for the principle that stability is of enormous benefit to a child, in the context of custody/removal modification, which aligns with the idea that stability of care and consistent parental availability are crucial considerations. However, this point is brief and primarily tied to removal rather than a broad discussion of all custody modifications, so support is somewhat indirect.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In light of the fact that more than three years have passed since the judgment was entered and the mother and the child relocated to Illinois, we conclude that a further evidentiary hearing is required... In determining the best interests of the child, weight, of course, should be given to the fact that ‘[stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003).”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: See also Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (modification justified where original custody arrangement no longer serves child’s welfare).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: This opinion is a direct appeal from the original divorce judgment addressing the initial custody determination, not a later request to modify a prior custody order. The court applies the ‘best interests of the child’ standard to decide between sole versus joint custody, but it does not discuss or apply any standard for modification of an existing custody arrangement that has become outdated or no longer serves the child’s welfare. Therefore, it does not provide authority for when modification of custody is justified.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings…. On this record we cannot say that the judge was clearly wrong in awarding sole custody to the wife.”
